comments:
Build ID: M20070921-1145

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Filetransfer tests with httpclient provider
2. set system locale to other than "en"
3. run tests

More information:
The filetransfer tests over http fail if the default locale is not "en". The resulting stack trace is, for instance (testReceiveFile):

The problem can be pinned down to HttpClientRetrieveFileTransfer.java, line 214:
lastModified = new SimpleDateFormat("EEE, d MMM yyyy HH:mm:ss z").parse(lastModifiedString).getTime(); //$NON-NLS-1$

SimpleDateFormat parses the weekday ("EEE") localized, whereas RFC 822/1123, as returned from the Http server, uses the English weekdays. If the default locale is not "en", the parsing fails. 

The problem can be resolved by changing this line to:

lastModified = new SimpleDateFormat("EEE, d MMM yyyy HH:mm:ss z", new Locale("en")).parse(lastModifiedString).getTime(); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$

(For performance reasons, both the creation of the SimpleDateFormat instance and the locale should rather be final fields of the class.)

(In reply to comment #0)
> SimpleDateFormat parses the weekday ("EEE") localized, whereas RFC 822/1123, as
> returned from the Http server, uses the English weekdays. If the default locale
> is not "en", the parsing fails.

Jan, thanks for the report and a suggested fix. Could you attach a patch to this bug?

Created an attachment (id=81334)
simple fix

simple fix, adds the "en" locale.

Created an attachment (id=81335)
optimized fix

optimized fix, factors out the SimpleDateFormat as a constant to avoid that a new instance is created for every response.

(In reply to comment #3)
> Created an attachment (id=81335) [details]
> optimized fix
> 
> optimized fix, factors out the SimpleDateFormat as a constant to avoid that a
> new instance is created for every response.
> 

Thanks very much Jan!

Applied patch and committed.  Added contribution to ip log.  Marking as fixed.

Thanks again.
Do we have a unit test in place to prevent regressions?

(In reply to comment #5)
> Do we have a unit test in place to prevent regressions?
> 

Not yet.  Ideally we would have a public http server that uses one of the non-rfc1123 date formats.  If we have that somewhere we can simply add access to it to one of the existing unit tests (or write additional ones).
